contentrichtext.text: {{about||the language|Slavey language}} [[File:Slavey girls Mackenzie River Northwest Territories - NA-1463-23.jpg|300px|thumb|Slavey girls, [[Mackenzie River]], [[Northwest Territories]]]] The '''Slavey''' (also '''Slave''') are a [[First Nations]] [[Aboriginal peoples of Canada|aboriginal people]] of the [[Dene]] group, [[indigenous peoples|indigenous]] to the [[Great Slave Lake]] region, in [[Canada]]'s [[Northwest Territories]], and extending into northeastern [[British Columbia]] and northwestern [[Alberta]]. ==Name== The name "Slave" is an English translation of the [[Cree]] name for their traditional enemies, including the people now known as the Slavey, whom they often enslaved; the French ''Esclave'' is analogous. However, in order to avoid the connotations of the word [[slavery|slave]], the name came to be presented as indigenous, and this was indicated by pronouncing the ''e''. Later the spelling was changed to ''Slavé'', and then ''Slavey'', to capture the new pronunciation. The name is seldom used by the Slavey, who call themselves ''[[Dene]].'' Because most [[Athabaskan]] peoples call themselves ''Dene'', the word is of little use in English.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} However, the northern Slavey are also known as the [[Sahtu|Sahtú]]. The southern band are known as the Deh Cho.<ref>http://www.dehcho.org</ref> The names of the [[Slave River]], [[Lesser Slave River]], [[Great Slave Lake]] and [[Lesser Slave Lake]] all derive from this Cree name for their enemies, though not necessarily from the people now known as ''Slavey'' in English. The term ''Esclaves'' remains incorporated in each of these geographical features' French names. == Groups == The [[Sahtu]] or [[North Slavey people]] live exclusively in the [[Northwest Territories]]. They speak the [[North Slavey language]]. The South Slavey live in [[Northern Alberta|north western Alberta]], north eastern British Columbia, and the southern Northwest Territories. The [[Dene Tha' First Nation]] in Alberta is a South Slavey nation. ==See also== * [[Slavey language]] * [[Broken Slavey]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Asch, Michael. ''Slavey Indians''.
